comments.author: Letty
comments.content: These Shasta lentils are new to me--thanks for sharing. Can you define non-tannin as it relates to lentils. I had never heard that either....

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Tannins in lentils are that same family of chemicals found in tea, oaked wines, etc that make your tongue feel dry. Lentils don't have a ton, so it isn't a huge issue or anything, but these zero-tannin lentils do come across as a bit sweeter and even more delicious. I guess there is some nutritional difference too: http://sanofibiogeneiuschallenge.ca/2012/04/25/saskatchewan-creating-a-better-lentil/

comments.author: Madeleine
comments.content: This looks delicious! It is always challenging to think of a dish to bring to a potluck besides the basic salad, and this seems like the perfect solution. Do you think the red onion could be substituted with a regular onion?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: For sure you could use a white onion or a sweet onion. If you were going to use a yellow onion, I'd reduce the amount or soak the cut pieces in a salt brine for 30 minutes to reduce the pungency a bit.
